clues.text: On his ninth birthday, this Dickens orphan is taken to live at the main work house by Mr. Bumble
Sisters Elinor & Marianne Dashwood are the heroines of this Jane Austen novel
"A Dead Man in Deptford", the last novel by this "A Clockwork Orange" author, was published in 1993
Loch Katrine provides the setting for his narrative poem "The Lady of the Lake"
This baroness whose first name is Phyllis is famous for mystery novels about detective Adam Dalgliesh
In 1995 she returned to Broadway in a 31st anniversary production of "Hello, Dolly!"
Pat Brown, former 2-term governor of this state, passed away in 1996
His recent country album "Tennessee Moon" features a new version of his hit "Kentucky Woman"
This celebrated hairstylist fought for the Israeli army during the 1948 War of Independence
In 1996 some of the top skaters joined Yekaterina Gordeyeva in a tribute to this late husband
Harrison Birtwistle wrote a 1968 opera about "Punch and" this partner
In an 1865 opera by Richard Wagner, Tristan is a tenor role & this heroine is a soprano
In a comic opera by Shostakovich, this facial feature detaches itself from Kovalev & leads a life of its own
It' traditional for a woman to play Cherubino the pageboy in this 1786 opera about a wedding
Leonore disguises herself as a boy known by this title name in a popular Beethoven opera
Victoria & Albert had a grand wedding breakfast at this palace before honeymooning at Windsor
The 19th C. hymn "Hold The Fort" was based on messages sent by this gen. known for his "March to the Sea"
Robert Fulton designed the demologos, the first warship powered by this
Nathaniel Hawthorne called his 1846 collection of tales "Mosses from an Old" one of these
Emile Zola's letter "J'accuse" helped win a new trial for this Frenchman who'd been convicted of spying
This variety of squash is named for its resemblance to the fruit of an oak tree
Popular in Israel, a sabra is the fruit of one of these prickly plants
It's the most popular fresh variety of grape grown in the U.S.
The English formerly referred to this flowering vegetable as "Italian asparagus"
The name of this long Asian radish is Japanese for "large root"
Dye some gauze in black tea for an aged look & wrap yourself up as this guy whom Abbott & Costello met in a 1955 film
Why not dress up as this Barrie character, the boy who would not grow up
Roll up the sleeves of a blue denim workshirt, put a red bandana in your hair & you can be this feminist WWII icon
A costume for 2: this double-crossing pair from Mad magazine, one in black & one in white, created by Antonio Prohias
If the guys are gangsters, wear fringed dresses & be these '20s gals found in a Fitzgerald title
George Weigel's biography of this onetime archbishop of Krakow is titled "Witness to Hope"
"A Covert Affair" serves up a spicy account of this TV chef & her work as a government agent during WWII
"Neither Shaken Nor Stirred" is the subtitle of Andrew Yule's biography of this actor
"Wanted!"  The real story of these 2 outlaw brothers in a 1981 biography of them
Arianna Huffington's biography of this painter was the basis for a 1996 film starring Anthony Hopkins
Smucker's blackberry & Jif's extra crunchy, in that order
We rewrite Shakespeare!  It's now lady first, please, in this nifty new title of a 1597 tragedy
In 1779 a certain college became the first in the U.S. to offer pro training in law; in 2015, we led with the queen & renamed it this
Time to give the climbing aspect top billing in this classic kids' game from Hasbro; the sliding part slides to the back end
We turn the fashion world upside down as D&G becomes G&D, this new brand; sorry, Domenico, Stefano is now No. 1
"Democracy returned" to this country "after a failed bid to seize the Falkland Islands"
It "is the third largest of the world's five oceans"
It "was attacked and overrun by Iraq on 2 August 1990"
The colors on its flag "were those of William I, Prince of Orange"
This West Indies British dependency has "transformed itself into a significant offshore financial center"
Lucan dropped Jupiter & Juno in the "Pharsalia", the rare ancient epic without these beings
"De Oratore" by this greatest Roman orator gives his views on using language effectively
Better known name of Titus Livius, author of a history of Rome from its founding to 9 B.C.
Dating from the 2nd century, this Roman emperor's "Meditations" is a classic of stoic philosophy
Julius Caesar described his victories in the 50s B.C. in what's now France in his "Commentaries on" these "Wars"
Title place where Michael Landon & Melissa Gilbert lived
clues.response: the Little House on the Prairie

clues.text: From 2005 to 2010, "Kathy Griffin" was followed by this subtitle
In the title of a long-running Richard Belzer series, it follows "Homicide"
This AMC Western is about railroads & revenge
We can't look away from this PBS series subtitled "America's Civil Rights Movement, 1954-1985"
Invented in 1948, the first dispenser for this candy resembled a lighter, to encourage people to quit smoking
These "tiny, tangy crunchy" candies from Wonka have a geeky name
The streetlights in the town of Hershey are shaped like these candies that were introduced in 1907
It calls itself the "crispety, crunchety" candy bar
This British chocolatier makes a dairy milk bar as well as a milk tray

rounds.text: Washington made the very first presidential proclamation in response to a request for "a day of public" this
